sen.j: 稚児髷(ちごまげ、ちごわげ)は、平安時代～安土桃山時代の少年の髪形、及び、それに類似した江戸時代から結われた少女の髪形。
sen.e: Chigomage (also pronounced "chigowage") is a form of hair which was worn by boys from Heian period to Azuchi-Momoyama period, and also the similar hairstyle for girls which dates from Edo period.

Chigomage (also pronounced "chigowage") is a form of hair which was worn by boys from the Heian period to the Azuchi-Momoyama period, and also the similar hairstyle for girls which dates from the Edo period.
sen.cmt: "Heian period", "Azuchi-Momoyama period", "Edo period"の前に"the"を追加
sen.e: Chigomage (also pronounced "chigowage") is a form of hair which was worn by boys from the Heian period to the Azuchi-Momoyama period, and also the similar hairstyle for girls which dates from the Edo period.

sen.j: 稚児輪(ちごわ)、唐輪(からわ)、唐子髷(からこまげ)とも呼ばれる。
sen.e: It is also called Chigowa, Karawa, and Karakomage.
It is also called Chigowa, Karawa, and Karakomage.
It is also called Chigowa, Karawa, and Karakomage.

tit.e: The way of dressing the hair
The way of dressing the hair
The way of dressing the hair

sen.j: 共通
sen.e: Common feature
Common feature
Common feature

sen.j: 頭頂部でひとつにまとめた髪を左右に分けてそれぞれ輪にし、毛先を根元に納めて幅広の丈長をかけて結い終わる。
sen.e: Bind the hair together at the top of the head and divide it into right and left, then make a loop with each of them tying their ends to the root of the ponytail; and finally the root is covered with broad takenaga (paper strip used as a hair ornament).

Bind the hair together at the top of the head and divide it into right and left, then make a loop with each of them tying their ends to the root of the ponytail; and finally the root is covered with broad takenaga (paper strip used as a hair ornament).

Bind the hair together at the top of the head and divide it into right and left, then make a loop with each of them tying their ends to the root of the ponytail; and finally the root is covered with broad takenaga (paper strip used as a hair ornament).

sen.j: 少年の髪形
sen.e: Hairstyle for boys
Hairstyle for boys
Hairstyle for boys

sen.j: 前髪を膨らませず、中央で左右に分ける。
sen.e: The forelocks are not puffed out and divided into right and left halves.
The forelocks are not puffed out and divided into right and left halves.
The forelocks are not puffed out and divided into right and left halves.

sen.j: 角前髪と同様に月代を剃る。
sen.e: Sakayaki (shaved part of the forehead) is shaved in the same way as Sumi-maegami (boys' hairstyle with cornered forelocks).
sen.cmt: 用語検索で「角前髪」は"sumi-maegami (boy with cornered forelocks)"となっていますが、()内を"boys' hairstyle with cornered forelocks"として使用しましたる
sen.e: Sakayaki (shaved part of the forehead) is shaved in the same way as Sumi-maegami (boys' hairstyle with cornered forelocks).
Sakayaki (shaved part of the forehead) is shaved in the same way as Sumi-maegami (boys' hairstyle with cornered forelocks).

sen.j: 平安時代に稚児＠大規模寺院の髪形として結われる様になり、後に皇族、平安貴族の少年の髪形として一般化する様になった。
sen.e: Chigomage originated as the hairstyle for chigo (child in a Buddhist possession) in major temples during Heian period, and later became commonly accepted as the hairstyle for boys of Imperial or noble family in the Heian period.

Chigomage originated as the hairstyle for chigo (child in a Buddhist possession) in major temples during the Heian period, and later became commonly accepted as the hairstyle for boys of Imperial or noble family in the Heian period.

Chigomage originated as the hairstyle for chigo (child in a Buddhist possession) in major temples during the Heian period, and later became commonly accepted as the hairstyle for boys of Imperial or noble family in the Heian period.

sen.j: 江戸時代以降は天皇家以外では殆ど姿を消した。
sen.e: After Edo period, it is rarely seen except for in the Imperial Family.
After the Edo period, it is rarely seen except for in the Imperial Family.
After the Edo period, it is rarely seen except for in the Imperial Family.

sen.j: 現代では極一部の歌舞伎舞踊や祭で見られるだけになった。
sen.e: Today it is only seen in very limited Kabuki Buyo (Kabuki Dance) and festivals.
Today it is only seen in very limited Kabuki Buyo (Kabuki Dance) and festivals.
Today it is only seen in very limited Kabuki Buyo (Kabuki Dance) and festivals.

sen.j: 少女の髪形
sen.e: Hairstyle for girls
Hairstyle for girls
Hairstyle for girls

sen.j: 江戸時代以降は少女の髪形として結われる様になった。
sen.e: Since Edo period chigomage became girls' hairstyle.
Since the Edo period chigomage became girls' hairstyle.
Since the Edo period chigomage became girls' hairstyle.

sen.j: 髷自体は少年の髪形と殆ど同じだが、前髪を眉尻の上辺りから広くとって上に上げるのが最大の特徴(おかっぱ頭の頭頂部に小さな髷を結う場合も多い、また幼い少女向きに前髪をとらないかたちもあった)。
sen.e: Although mage (a chignon) itself is almost the same as in boys' hairstyle, the most distinctive feature of girls' hair is that the forelocks are widely brought up from above the outer ends of the eyebrows (there are also many cases in which a small mage is worn at the top of the bobbed hair, and for very young girls sometimes the forelocks were not brought up).

Although mage (a chignon) itself is almost the same as in boys' hairstyle, the most distinctive feature of girls' hair is that the forelocks are widely brought up from above the outer ends of the eyebrows (there are also many cases in which a small mage is worn at the top of the bobbed hair, and for very young girls sometimes the forelocks were not brought up).

Although mage (a chignon) itself is almost the same as in boys' hairstyle, the most distinctive feature of girls' hair is that the forelocks are widely brought up from above the outer ends of the eyebrows (there are also many cases in which a small mage is worn at the top of the bobbed hair, and for very young girls sometimes the forelocks were not brought up).

sen.j: 本来髪飾りは一切使用しないが、大正の初期ごろから花簪などを挿して飾るようになった。
sen.e: Originally no hair ornaments were used for chigomage, but from the beginning of the Taisho period people began to ornament it with hana-kanzashi (flower ornament) and so on.
Originally no hair ornaments were used for chigomage, but from the beginning of the Taisho period people began to ornament it with hana-kanzashi (flower ornament) and so on.
Originally no hair ornaments were used for chigomage, but from the beginning of the Taisho period people began to ornament it with hana-kanzashi (flower ornament) and so on.

sen.j: 10代の少女の場合は桃割れや銀杏返しに類似した髪形となる場合も多い。
sen.e: When girls between 10 and 19 years old wear chigomage, it often becomes similar to Momoware (literally, split peach; female hair style in kimono that the bun is split and a red fabric woven in the center) or Ichogaeshi (the hair done up in a bun shaped like two leaves of the ginkgo tree).

When girls between 10 and 19 years old wear chigomage, it often becomes similar to Momoware (literally, split peach; female hair style in kimono that the bun is split and a red fabric woven in the center) or Ichogaeshi (the hair done up in a bun shaped like two leaves of the ginkgo tree).

When girls between 10 and 19 years old wear chigomage, it often becomes similar to Momoware (literally, split peach; female hair style in kimono that the bun is split and a red fabric woven in the center) or Ichogaeshi (the hair done up in a bun shaped like two leaves of the ginkgo tree).

sen.j: 特に身分の高い武家や公家の姫君の側近くに仕える、五、六歳から十二歳ぐらいの「お小姓」（大名などに仕える武家の少年使用人である小姓とは別）と呼ばれる少女によく結われた髪型。
sen.e: This hairstyle was worn by the girls called 'Okosho' (it is different from child servants of samurai family called "Kosho," who paged to daimyo [Japanese feudal lord] and so on), who was aged between five or six and 12 years old and attended on a daughter of a high-ranking samurai or a court noble.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: This hairstyle was worn by the girls called 'Okosho' (it is different from child servants of samurai family called "Kosho," who paged to daimyo [Japanese feudal lord] and so on), who was aged between five or six and 12 years old and attended on a daughter of a high-ranking samurai or a court noble.

This hairstyle was worn by the girls called 'Okosho' (it is different from child servants of samurai family called "Kosho," who paged to daimyo [Japanese feudal lord] and so on), who was aged between five or six and 12 years old and attended on a daughter of a high-ranking samurai or a court noble.

sen.j: 簡単に結う事が出来、古風で可憐で気品があることから明治から昭和戦前に掛けて一部の幼稚園・小学校(いわゆるお嬢様学校)では稚児髷に紫袴を制服に制定した(中学生以上は束髪)。
sen.e: Because it is easy to do the hair in chigomage and it is an old-fashioned, cute and refined hairstyle; from the Meiji period to prewar days in the Showa period some kindergartens and elementary schools (so-called "Ojosama gakko," schools for rich young ladies) adopted chigomage and purple hakama (pleated and divided skirt made in fine stripes) as their regulation uniform (for students of junior high school or above, Western hairdo was adopted).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Because it is easy to do the hair in chigomage and it is a traditional, cute and refined hairstyle; from the Meiji period to prewar days in the Showa period some kindergartens and elementary schools (so-called "Ojosama gakko," schools for rich young ladies) adopted chigomage and purple hakama (pleated and divided skirt made in fine stripes) as their regulation uniform (students of junior high school or above wore swept-back hair with the bun at the back of the head).
sen.cmt: "an old-fashioned"を"a traditional"に変更"for students of junior high school or above, Western hairdo was adopted"を"students of junior high school or above wore swept-back hair with the bun at the back of the head"に変更
sen.e: Because it is easy to do the hair in chigomage and it is a traditional, cute and refined hairstyle; from the Meiji period to prewar days in the Showa period some kindergartens and elementary schools (so-called "Ojosama gakko," schools for rich young ladies) adopted chigomage and purple hakama (pleated and divided skirt made in fine stripes) as their regulation uniform (students of junior high school or above wore swept-back hair with the bun at the back of the head).

sen.j: 現在でも七五三や十三参り、祭礼などに参加する少女が結うことがある(但し、現在では晴れ着の少女の髪形は結綿や勝山髷が主流で稚児髷は思ったほど多くない)。
sen.e: Even now chigomage is sometimes worn by girls when they take part in Shichi-go-san (a day of prayer for the healthy growth of young children) events, Jusan Mairi (a visit to a shrine or temple to celebrate being 13 years old), festivals and so on (however, today gaily dressed girls mainly wear Yuiwata [hair style like cotton wrapped up] or Katsuyama-mage [hair style with combs and pins], so that chigomage is not to be seen very often).
sen.cmt: 用語検索で「十三参り」は"Jusan Mairi (visit shrines and temples to celebrate being 13 years old)"となっていますが、()内を"a visit to a shrine or temple to celebrate being 13 years old"として使用しました。
sen.e: Even now chigomage is sometimes worn by girls when they take part in Shichi-go-san (a day of prayer for the healthy growth of young children) events, Jusan Mairi (a visit to a shrine or temple to celebrate being 13 years old), festivals and so on (however, today gaily dressed girls mainly wear Yuiwata [hair style like cotton wrapped up] or Katsuyama-mage [hair style with combs and pins], so that chigomage is not to be seen very often).

Even now chigomage is sometimes worn by girls when they take part in Shichi-go-san (a day of prayer for the healthy growth of young children) events, Jusan Mairi (a visit to a shrine or temple to celebrate being 13 years old), festivals and so on (however, today gaily dressed girls mainly wear Yuiwata [hair style like cotton wrapped up] or Katsuyama-mage [hair style with combs and pins], so that chigomage is not to be seen very often).

sen.j: 稚児髷が見られる祭り等
sen.e: Festivals and so on in which chigomage is to be seen
Festivals and so on in which chigomage is to be seen
Festivals and so on in which chigomage is to be seen

sen.j: 現代に於いては稚児髷は、思ったほど多くは見られない。
sen.e: Today chigomage is not to be seen very often.
Today chigomage is not to be seen very often.
Today chigomage is not to be seen very often.

sen.j: それを見る事が出来る祭りや、舞踊作品、等をここで挙げる。
